I.  THE ONGOING PROGRAM 
 
1.  Trade finance is explicitly recognized in the Addis Ababa Action Agenda on Financing for 
Development as important to achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals 
(SDGs).1 However, an ADB survey published in September 2019 estimated a global trade finance 
gap of $1.5 trillion, with small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and women-led businesses 
being the most underserved.2 This gap has widened during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) 
pandemic. The International Chamber of Commerce (ICC) anticipates that an additional $1.9 
trillion–$5 trillion is required to support a rapid global recovery.3 
 
2.  ADB’s Trade Finance Program (TFP) reduces market gaps for trade finance by (i) 
providing guarantees and loans to banks, and undertaking funded and unfunded risk participation, 
in support of trade; and (ii) delivering knowledge products, services and solutions. The TFP’s 
impact would be to strengthen the capacity of domestic financial institutions to encourage and 
expand access to banking, insurance, and financial services for all. This will be achieved by 
increasing access of DMC banks to trade finance through the program. The outcome of the 
program would be expansion of support for trade finance in Asia and the Pacific, while outputs 
include (i) capacity to provide trade finance by the program’s partner banks enhanced in a gender-
inclusive manner, (ii) the expanded provision of trade finance sustained, (iii) gender inclusiveness 
of participating banks’ human resource policies enhanced, (iv) zccess to international trade 
finance of women-owned businesses enhanced, and (v) environmental and social safeguards 
awareness for both the TFP and its partner banks increased. 
 
3.  TFP’s current program limit is $2.15 billion. Since its launch in 2003, TFP has supported 
over $48 billion in trade and mobilized $28 billion in co-financing. In 2020, the number of 
transactions supported by TFP increased by 49%, to 7,178 from 4,832 in 2019. The value of 
transactions grew by 7%, to $5.8 billion from $5.4 billion in 2019. TFP is ADB’s largest business 
and generator of co-financing, contributing $3 billion in co-financing in 2020. The TFP conducts 
approximately 100 due diligence and annual reviews per year, enabling it to provide guarantees 
and loans through partner banks. This closes market gaps for trade finance and supports more 
trade, leading to economic growth and job creation. Information from due diligence and annual 
reviews  enables  TFP  to  share  knowledge  that  helps  attract  co-financing  and  international 
investment in developing member countries (DMCs), thereby closing trade finance market gaps.  
 
4.  The onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in early 2020 continues to pose an immense 
challenge for global trade and the economic growth of many DMCs. It underscores the need to 
support trade not only to move medical supplies but also to bolster economies. The TFP is an 
excellent crisis response vehicle, with an extensive global network of 200 partner financial 
institutions through which support can be channeled quickly and efficiently, including to small and 
medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which are the entities most likely impacted by the pandemic.  
TFP is central to ADB’s response to the COVID-19 pandemic.4 Of the 7,178 transactions 
supported under TFP, 5,467 were COVID-related transactions worth $4.5 billion for the purchase 
of goods such as test kits and medical equipment. These supported (i) companies that provide 
essential services and (ii) financial intermediaries that provide direct financing to individual

companies, including SMEs, or facilitate local, regional, and global trade and related supply 
chains that have been materially affected by the pandemic’s economic fallout.  
 
5.  TFP also encourages commercial sustainability by helping accelerate progress in gender 
equality, promoting sustainability in trade, and ensuring integrity and transparency. In addition, 
TFP produced targeted knowledge products such as the COVID-19 supply chain tool,5 webinars 
about managing COVID-19 trade finance risk and digitization, webinars on other issues and online 
training. In 2020, TFP conducted 10 webinars with over 1,200 participants.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster 
6.  The technical assistance cluster was approved by the Board on 11 April 2018 and 
complements ADB's non-sovereign operations in trade and trade facilitation projects.6 It is linked 
to ADB’s Operational Plan for Private Sector Operations, 2019–2024, as well numerous strategies 
and business opportunities presented in country strategy papers, regional cooperation strategies 
and programs, and country operations business plans for ADB's DMCs.7 The technical assistance 
cluster builds on ongoing work under TA projects started in 2009, 2013, 2014, and 2015.8 
 
7.  Subproject 1 (TA 9532), subproject 2 (TA 9774) and subproject 3 (TA 6547) funded TFP’s 
due diligence activities on partner banks from May 2018 to present. To date, 42 new issuing bank 
assessments, 15 preliminary analyses of potential TFP issuing bank candidates, 281 bank 
monitoring assessments, 47 banking system analyses, 40 new/annual reviews of partner financial 
institutions (PFIs), 10 new/annual reviews of existing risk distribution partners and 6 training 
sessions/workshops have been delivered. Subproject 1 was completed last 5 July 2020 while 
subprojects  2  and  3  have  been  extended  until  31  December  2021  and  31  March  2023, 
respectively, to align the duration of the subprojects with the engagement period of consultants 
and to allow TFP to use the remaining budget for upcoming training and events.  
 
B.  Subproject Scope  
8.  Similar to the subprojects 1-3, subproject 4 will provide the TFP with funding to conduct 
due diligence on partner banks and financial institutions. Financial analysts will be engaged 
through a firm from 2021 to 2022 to work with the TFP to conduct due diligence and ongoing 
annual reviews of participating banks and partner financial institutions. Subproject 4 will also 
include activities related to the program’s gender, sustainability and integrity initiatives as well as 
capacity building through seminars, including webinars and other online trainings. 
 
 
5   A new tool https://www.adb.org/multimedia/scf/ was published in May 2020 on the ADB website that maps, end-to-end the entire 
supply chain for 33 critical pandemic-fighting goods, such as ventilators, N95 masks, etc. The tool helps banks, investors and 
government ensure companies have no bottlenecks and financial support is there to ramp up supply.

C.  Subproject Outputs and Activities  
9.  Output 1: Capacity to provide trade finance and guarantees by developing member 
country banks enhanced. Assessments of new and existing banks and PFIs will be conducted 
under the TA by consultants who will support TFP relationship managers (ADB international staff). 
Due diligence on banks will enable ADB to identify and characterize any gaps in the financial and 
technical capacity of individual banks that would inhibit the provision and/or increase of trade 
finance credit lines.9 DMC banks are targeted based on a market survey conducted by the TFP. 
If there is market demand for TFP guarantees on a particular DMC bank, the bank will be targeted 
for due diligence and inclusion into the program.10 The due diligence results will be included in 
credit applications to establish or maintain TFP credit lines for participating banks.  
 
10.  Output  2:    Trade  finance  in-person  and/or  online  trainings,  seminars  and/or 
webinars and other networking events conducted. Approximately 2 in-person and/or online 
training sessions, seminars or webinars will be conducted under Subproject 4. The TFP provides 
post-due diligence feedback to DMC banks to identify weaknesses and improvement benchmarks. 
This capacity development will help strengthen DMC banks and improve their ability to attract 
credit lines to support trade from international financial institutions. This will ultimately benefit 
importers and exporters by increasing their opportunities to access trade finance, allowing them 
to expand their business operations, and thereby create jobs and reduce poverty. 
 
11.  Information regarding the adequacy of the financial and technical capacity of individual 
banks will be confidentially conveyed to those banks. More general information about trade 
finance operations will be disseminated through seminars, webinars and other online training to 
which DMC banks, exporters, government officials, and international banks may be invited. These 
are expected to cover (i) key concepts and processes in trade finance, (ii) essential elements in 
developing and marketing trade finance products and services, (iii) payment and risk categories, 
(iv) risk analysis of trade finance products, (v) fundamentals of documentary credits, (vii) de-
risking and anti-money laundering compliance methods, and (viii) digitization of trade finance. The 
TA will also be used to fund regional seminars and other TFP training events, as well as an annual 
networking event, online or otherwise, which will bring together international and local DMC banks 
and seek to increase private sector engagement with DMCs. 
 
12.  Output 3: Gender and safeguards-related in-person and/or online training, seminars 
and/or webinars conducted. The aim of the gender initiative is more financial inclusion and 
support for individual women and women entrepreneurs. Gender initiatives will continue to be 
implemented within the TFP and will set a minimum threshold of 40% for the percentage of female 
participants in all of its training. The TFP’s gender initiative is in progress with human resource 
policies of 19 partner banks in 8 DMCs reviewed to identify enhancements to attract, retain, 
and promote women in banking.11 Resource persons will be engaged to develop and come up 
with knowledge products such as in-person and/or online training, seminars and/or webinars, and 
networking for DMC partner banks focused on improving the banks’ customer service for female 
clientele, as well as for women-owned businesses centered on increasing their access to trade 
finance.   
 
13.  On the sustainability front,  the TA will build on work done under previous and ongoing 
TFP TAs to create more awareness of and help address social and environmental issues such

the Pacific region (e.g., Samoa and Vanuatu).

4 
as child/forced labor, climate change and sustainability through the banking sector, which is 
expected to also impact banks’ clients, including SMEs.12 TFP will conduct safeguards in-person 
and/or online training, and seminars and/or webinars to deepen its partner banks’ awareness and 
understanding of environmental and social safeguards and enhance their safeguards capacity. 
 
14.  Output 4: Integrity due diligence and reviews completed on TFP developing member 
country  banks  and  partner  financial  institutions.  Following  the  global  financial  crisis, 
compliance and regulatory requirements have increased significantly for banks, including in the 
field of trade finance. Unintended consequences of anti-money-laundering and counter-financing 
of terrorism (AML/CFT) measures contribute to market gaps. The TA will support strengthening 
of AML/CFT practices by funding related online training and preparation for the Financial Action 
Task Force (FATF) Working Group on Trade-Based Money Laundering events in various DMCs. 
Consultants will also be engaged to strengthen integrity and anti-money laundering measures 
and monitoring by conducting sanctions screening on TFP transactions and integrity due diligence 
and reviews on all TFP DMC banks and PFIs. 
 
15.  Activities will include the following: 
(i)  work with individual banks to acquire financial data; 
(ii)  analyze the financial information through financial, ratio, gap, and other analyses; 
(iii)  conduct financial due diligence on banks; 
(iv)  assess the trade finance operations capacity of selected banks and make 
recommendations for improvement; 
(v)  draft credit applications, risk ratings, and financial due diligence reports; 
(vi)  conduct integrity due diligence and reviews, including monitoring and following- 
up on recommendations for improvement; 
(vii)  conduct due diligence and financial assessments on TFP banks with a view to 
expanding and leveraging the TFP to include additional ADB financial products; 
(viii)  conduct a banking sector analysis for each DMC; 
(ix)  conduct signing with new partner banks;  
(x)  deliver trade finance in-person and/or online training, and seminars and/or 
webinars;  
(xi)  process and administer TFP loans and guarantees transactions, and monitor 
program and counterparty limits; 
(xii)  support initiatives related to knowledge-sharing and partnership development 
activities important to closing trade finance gaps such as those related to gender, 
sustainability and AML/CFT (including in-person and/or online training, regional 
conferences, seminars and/or webinars, and networking events, which may be 
done through online facilities); and 
(xiii)  conduct relevant sanctions screening for all TFP transactions. 
 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $3,700,000, of which (i) $2,194,372 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-donor contribution), and (ii) $1,505,628 
will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-income 
transfer).  The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
12  ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance for Capacity Development for Expansion of the Trade Finance Program into the Pacific and 
Enhanced Safeguards and Integrity Measures for Trade Finance Program Banks. Manila; and ADB. 2018. Technical Assistance 
for Capacity Building for Enhanced Safeguards, Anti-Corruption and Integrity Measures, Gender Equity Policies and Digitization of 
Trade Finance Program Banks. Manila.

17.  ADB will administer the subproject. PSOD will select, supervise and evaluate consultants 
as well as resource persons that will be engaged for in-person and/or online training, regional 
conferences, and seminars and/or webinars.
